instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight. Original damage is severe burn where backlight fuse goes. Replaced backlight fuse and have fused soldered directly to pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> and wire running to <RESISTOR>R7006</RESISTOR> for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> however every time the backlight starts to activate the wire just burns and separates.

What else should I try?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message:
You should check if any short persists on the board, BEFORE applying power.
Check w/ and w/o LCD connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message:
without wire there is no short w/wo lcd but with new wire ran there is a 0.54 short on F7700 w/o lcd and w lcd 0.38

how do you solve something like this besides just scraping away at affected area more?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message:
Do you mean 0.38-0.54 on diode mode?
That is no short at all.
I expected you will check on pins 3/4 of J8300, not only F7700.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message: Yes readings on pins 3/4 is .572 but jumper wire still burns each time the backlight starts to activate

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message:
Did you check on the jumper wire too?
No short or low value?
Pad 2 of F7700 can be damaged and shorted to second copper layer, which is ground.
If is the case, isolate pad 2 and wire pad1 to pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR> makes contact too.
Also check no short remains on the board, before apply power; especially <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message:
With a wire on F7700 going to pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> and pad 1 of F770 being isolate (no wire to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) there is no short 0.806 on diode mode but still smokes when power is applied with or without lcd.

picture attached of damaged area

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message: Smoke comes from a component or board itself?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse
threads.message:
Scratch inside the board in that place.
Make a hole in the surface (first layers), and polish the edge.
